page.title: 12LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS
page.content: The landscape is almost wholly man-made.Only the cliffs can be considered a "natural" feature.{ {LANDSCAPE}This area varies from open wind-swept cliff-top where rough grass alternates with thick furze,to the maze of narrow lanes burrowing between earthen banks which make field boundaries.The cliffs are cleft into steep valleys by unobtrusive streams and in these there is thick woodland. In Spring the area blazes with wild flowers,in Autumn there is a generous harvest of blackberries and sloes. Inland there is a quiet landscape where buildings and small,irregular fields can be glimpsed briefly over the earthbanks and hedges.{BUILDINGS} Originally there were only farmhouses, often 2 or 3 close to one another,in the midst of their fields sharing the cliff-top pastures.These are granite
